questions.text: Which of these options is not a causal factor for head and neck malignancies? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin A deficiency

 

Vitamin A deficiency is not recognized as a direct risk factor for head and neck malignancies. While vitamin A plays crucial roles in maintaining epithelial tissues and immune function, its deficiency primarily leads to issues like night blindness and immune deficiencies, rather than directly causing cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus) infection: EBV is associated with various types of cancers, including nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It is a well-established risk factor for this specific type of head and neck cancer.

 

Option B. HPV (Human Papillomavirus) infection: HPV, particularly type 16, is a significant risk factor for oropharyngeal cancers. The virus can lead to cellular transformations that result in malignancy.

 

Option Betel nut: Consumption of betel nut, often part of a "paan" or betel quid, is a known risk factor for oral cancers, particularly in the gingivobuccal sulcus, common in regions where it is a cultural practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common risk factors known to cause head and neck malignancies includes:

 

  1. Alcohol use
  2. Tobacco use (smoking or chewing)
  3. Viruses
    1. HPV 16 - oropharyngeal cancer
    2. EBV – Nasopharyngeal cancer
  4. Paan (betel quid) – Oral cancers especially in gingivobuccal sulcus
  5. Preserved or salted food consumption - nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  6. Occupational exposure:
    1. Exposure to wood or nickel dust or formaldehyde - a risk factor for cancers of the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity
    2. Radiation exposure is a risk factor for salivary gland tumors, thyroid gland carcinoma

questions.text: A young woman, aged 25, presented with hearing impairment that emerged shortly after her initial pregnancy. Provided below is her audiometry findings. What could be the potential diagnosis for this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otosclerosis

 

Hearing loss that developed shortly after the first pregnancy along with Carhart's notch seen in the audiogram is suggestive of otosclerosis.

 

Interpretation of the given audiogram:

 

  • Blue color indicates the left ear.
  • x indicates AC and threshold is >15 dB and hence AC is abnormal. So it indicates conductive deafness.
  • ] indicates BC and threshold is <25dB. A characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz called Carhart’s notch is seen.
  • The air-bone gap is a feature of conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence, left-sided otosclerosis is the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Ototoxicity causes SNHL and shows a high-frequency hearing loss in the SNHL curve.

 

Option B: Meniere's disease shows a low-frequency loss in the SNHL curve.

 

 

Option D: Noise-induced hearing loss - PTA shows a characteristic Acoustic dip at 4000 Hz (Boiler’s Notch).

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A gentleman presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a past history of cough, on/off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with pale granuloma. His chest x-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleated giant cells, and caseous necrosis. What would be the probable cause? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

Generalized symptoms of fever, productive cough, weight loss, night sweats, and hemoptysis along with chest x-ray showing multiple cavitation lesions are suggestive of tuberculosis. This diagnosis is supported by:

 

  • Chest X-ray: Presence of multiple cavitary lesions, which are characteristic of pulmonary TB.
  • Biopsy Findings: The presence of granulomas, multinucleated giant cells (Langhans type), and caseous necrosis is indicative of TB, which involves granulomatous inflammation with a distinctive type of necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener's Granulomatosis: This could also present with nasal deformity and granulomas but is usually associated with vasculitis and lacks the caseous necrosis typical of TB.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Can cause nasal collapse ("saddle nose") but typically does not present with the lung involvement seen in TB.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Also presents with granulomas but lacks the caseous necrosis seen in TB and typically shows non-cavitary lung lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis should be considered in patients presenting with respiratory symptoms, systemic signs, and nasal deformities when accompanied by histological evidence of caseating granulomas. This constellation of findings is distinct in suggesting TB over other granulomatous diseases.

 

Granulomatous Disease of the Nose:

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 -1 - 3 - 4- 5

 

The auditory pathway begins at the peripheral sensory receptors and progresses through a series of nuclei and tracts in the central nervous system before reaching the auditory cortex. The correct sequence from the periphery to the higher centers is:

 

  • Spiral ganglion (2): Located in Rosenthal's canal within the cochlea, the spiral ganglion contains bipolar neurons that send fibers through the cochlear nerve (part of the eighth cranial nerve) to the brainstem.
  • Cochlear nucleus (1): The first central auditory nucleus where the cochlear nerve fibers terminate.
  • Superior olivary nucleus (3): Serves as a major binaural processing center in the brainstem, crucial for localizing sounds in space.
  • Inferior colliculus (4): Acts as an important relay station in the midbrain, integrating auditory input before sending it to the thalamus.
  • Medial geniculate body (5): Part of the thalamus, this structure further processes auditory information before transmitting it to the auditory cortex.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA).

  1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve

  2. Cochlear Nucleus

  3. Superior Olivary nucleus

  4. Lateral lemniscus

  5. Inferior colliculus

  6. Medial geniculate body

  7. Auditory cortex

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 15

choices.text: Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. On examination, the doctor diagnose Otosclerosis and recommends stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests based on which the doctor has recommended stapedectomy? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Typical of otosclerosis, indicating conductive hearing loss where BC > AC.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Indicates that the sound is heard better in the ear with more conductive loss, which matches otosclerosis more severely affecting the right ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Indicates that air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC), which is a normal finding and typically not expected in conductive hearing loss like otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: In a case of unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss, Weber's test lateralizes to the better hearing ear in sensorineural hearing loss and to the poorer ear in conductive hearing loss. This pattern does not fit otosclerosis affecting the right ear more severely.

 

Option B. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Again, indicates normal AC > BC, not typical for otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Would suggest either a sensorineural hearing loss on the left ear or less likely conductive loss on the right, which doesn’t match typical otosclerosis findings.

 

Option C. Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Indicates that BC > AC, suggesting conductive hearing loss, typical of otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: Would imply the left ear is either better or has conductive loss, not aligning with greater hearing loss in the right ear due to otosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of a negative Rinne test and Weber test lateralizing to the ear with more hearing loss is indicative of conductive hearing loss in that ear. In otosclerosis, the ossification of the stapes leads to mechanical dysfunction, preventing effective sound transmission, hence a stapedectomy might be recommended to mechanically bypass the ossified stapes and improve hearing.

choices.text: Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

questions.text: A patient present with oral cavity findings as seen in the image below. He is a smoker. What would you choose as your next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

 

  • The next step of management of this patient will be cessation of smoking and do a biopsy.
  • The patient is a chronic smoker and the following image shows leukoplakia. Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity.

 

The management include: 

 

  1. Elimination of associated aetiological factors and biopsy of the lesion. Many of the lesions will disappear spontaneously if the causative agent is removed.
  2. In lesions with higher potential for malignant change, a biopsy is taken to rule out malignancy.
  3. In suspicious small lesions, surgical excision or ablation with laser or cryotherapy can be done.

 

A photographic record of the lesion is useful for long term follow up.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give corticosteroids: There is no role for corticosteroids in the treatment of leukoplakia as they do not address the potential for malignant transformation or the underlying causes of the lesion.

 

Option C. Lifestyle Modifications: While beneficial overall, lifestyle changes alone are insufficient for managing a lesion with potential malignancy. Specific interventions like quitting smoking are required.

 

Option D. Injection vitamin B12: There is no indication that vitamin B12 injections would be effective in treating leukoplakia unless there is a specific deficiency that also needs addressing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For leukoplakia, particularly in smokers, the primary management strategy includes cessation of smoking and histological examination through biopsy. This is crucial not only to assess the current state of the lesion but also to guide further therapeutic decisions which may include surgical excision, laser ablation, or cryotherapy depending on the biopsy results. Regular monitoring and photographic documentation of the lesion are also important for long-term follow-up.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 253

questions.text: A senior ENT specialist at the hospital is conducting the clinical examination depicted in the provided image. Which of the subsequent anatomical structures will not be visible to him? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arytenoids

 

While conducting a posterior rhinoscopy with the held post-nasal mirror, the specialist would not have a view of the arytenoids.

 

  • Arytenoids are seen on indirect laryngoscopy.
  • The posterior rhinoscopy mirror has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.
  • The structures seen in posterior rhinoscopy are:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoids: These are clearly visible during posterior rhinoscopy, which is aimed at examining the nasopharynx, where the adenoids are located.

 

Option C. Torus tubarius: This structure, which surrounds the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube, is also visible during a posterior rhinoscopy.

 

Option D. Upper surface of soft palate: This area can be inspected during posterior rhinoscopy for signs of inflammation, lesions, or other abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The arytenoids are viewed using indirect laryngoscopy, not posterior rhinoscopy, due to their location in the larynx. Posterior rhinoscopy provides visualization of the nasopharyngeal region, aiding in the assessment of structures like adenoids, torus tubarius, and the upper surface of the soft palate, important for diagnosing various nasopharyngeal conditions.

 

Additional Information

 

Structures seen on indirect laryngoscopy

choices.text: Making him sit in front row in class

questions.text: A child has bilateral SNHL. Which of the following is not preferred in the child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

Adenoidectomy with Grommet Insertion: This procedure is primarily used to treat chronic adenoiditis and otitis media with effusion (OME), which are associated with conductive hearing loss (CHL), not SNHL. Since the child has SNHL, this treatment is not appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) indicates that there is a problem in the inner ear (cochlea) or the auditory nerve. When treating bilateral SNHL in a child, certain interventions are preferred based on the underlying pathology and the severity of the hearing loss.

 

Option A. Cochlear Implant: This is a viable option for children with severe to profound SNHL where the cochlea is affected but the auditory nerve is intact. The implant bypasses the damaged cochlea and directly stimulates the auditory nerve, allowing the child to hear.

 

Option C. Making him sit in front row in class: This is a common accommodation to help children with hearing loss to better hear and engage in classroom activities. It minimizes the distance between the child and the teacher, thus reducing the impact of hearing loss.

 

Option D.  Hearing Aid: This is suitable for children with mild to moderate SNHL. Hearing aids amplify sounds, making them louder and easier to hear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is not preferred for treating bilateral sensorineural hearing loss as it addresses conditions causing conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. Single ipsilateral < 3cm node is seen. What is the staging? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. T4N1M0

The given CT image is consistent with a staging of T4N1M0. It depicts a large glottic-subglottic mass with massive cricoid and thyroid invasion and extra laryngeal spread indicating a T4 stage.

Above shown is CT scan of a 72-year-old patient with T4a laryngeal cancer (red arrows) showing a large extralaryngeal extension through the left side of the thyroid cartilage. Indication of primary total laryngectomy.

Other Options:

Option A. T1N0M0: Would indicate a tumor confined to one subsite with no lymph node involvement or distant metastasis, which does not correlate with the extensive involvement shown in the image.

Option C. T2N1M0: Suggests tumor involvement of adjacent subsites or impaired vocal cord mobility, which is less extensive than that shown.

Option D. T3N0M0: Indicates more advanced local disease than T2 but without the extensive extra-laryngeal spread or significant lymph node involvement shown in the image.

Educational Objective:

TNM STAGING FOR CA LARYNX:

T1 – Only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis)

T2 – Involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility.

T3 – Involving Pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords.

T4a – Local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx

T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc)

N0 – No cervical lymph nodes

N1 – Single ipsilateral < 3cm

N2 – Single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm

N3 – Single or multiple nodes > 6cm

M0 – No metastasis

M1 – Metastasis present

Ref: Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 348

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS (Functional endoscopic sinus surgery) for failed conservative management 5 years ago. Uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation was done during the previous FESS. A DNE done now shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroid irrigation and antihistamines

 

The next best step in management in this patient is steroid irrigation and antihistamines.

 

This patient who had previously undergone FESS 5 years ago for failed medical management now has nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip suggestive of acute rhinosinusitis.

 

Acute rhinosinusitis usually develops along with viral upper respiratory tract infection due to mucosal swelling causing obstruction of the sinus ostia. Persistent or worsening symptoms even after 10 days with fever and purulent discharge indicates secondary bacterial infection.

 

Treatment initially is symptomatic with -

 

  • First line of treatment - Nasal steroid irrigation, decongestants, and antihistamines
  • In cases of secondary bacterial infection antibiotics are indicated. Amoxyclav is the drug of choice.
  • Biological therapy is not used in the treatment of sinusitis. It may be used in cases of refractory polyp.
  • Revision surgery is indicated only when maximal medical therapy has failed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat Surgery: Indicated only if there are anatomical obstructions or complications that cannot be managed medically. In this case, the DNE shows patent ostia, so repeat surgery is not indicated without further evidence of structural issues.

 

Option B. Macrolides for 4 months: Could be considered for their anti-inflammatory properties in some chronic rhinosinusitis cases, but there is no mention of bacterial infection needing long-term antibiotics, making this less suitable than symptomatic management.

 

Option D. Biological Therapy: Mainly used for refractory cases with specific underlying conditions such as severe asthma or nasal polyps, which is not indicated here based on the provided scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip post-FESS with no current acute infection or structural issues, conservative management using steroid irrigation and antihistamines is recommended to manage inflammation and alleviate symptoms.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 213, 214

questions.text: In what situations does Gelle's test yield a negative result?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Otosclerosis

 

  • Gelle's test is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed as in case of otosclerosis.
  • Gelle's test –  Increased pressure in the ear canal by Siegel's speculum, pushes the tympanic membrane and ossicles inwards raising the intralabyrinthine pressure and reducing the mobility of the basilar membrane leading to decreased hearing. This is called as Gelle’s positive seen in normal and SNHL patients.
  • No change in hearing on applying pressure is Gelle’s negative, seen in ossicular chain fixation or discontinuity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSOM with Cholesteatoma: In case of CSOM with cholesteatoma, the pressure increased by the seigel’s speculum will directly push the cholesteatoma onto the ossicles (there is no fixation of ossicles here) and then there will be increased intralabyrinthine pressure. Hence Gelle will be positive.

 

Option B. Senile deafness: In case of senile deafness (presbycusis), there will be sensorineural hearing loss and it is due to natural aging of the hair cells. The ossicles will be mobile normally and hence Gelle will be positive.

 

Option C. Meniere’s disease: In case of Meniere’s disease also, the ossicles are not involved. On siegelisation, the inward pushed TM and ossicles will raise intralabyrinthine pressure, thereby making Gelle test positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gelle’s test is instrumental in diagnosing conditions involving ossicular chain mobility. A negative Gelle's test, indicating ossicular fixation, is particularly indicative of otosclerosis, which is crucial for determining appropriate management strategies, including potential surgical interventions like stapedectomy for improving hearing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 24, 25

questions.text:
What are the objective tests used to assess hearing?

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective hearing tests are those that do not require a response from the patient and are used to assess hearing ability or the integrity of parts of the hearing pathway.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system.

 

 

 

Other Option:

 

3. Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA): PTA requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. It tests the hearing threshold levels of an individual, enabling determination of the degree, type, and configuration of a hearing loss, thus classifying it as a subjective test.

 

Other examples of subjective tests include tuning fork tests and speech audiometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective tests such as BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic data without requiring any active response from the patient, thus suitable for use in patients who may not be able to respond reliably, such as young children or those with certain disabilities.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 25, 26, 29

questions.text: A 22-year-old man has arrived with a gradual swelling on the left side of his face persisting for two weeks. He had a prior incident of trauma involving wood, which occurred two months ago. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasal passages and paranasal sinuses reveals a mass within the subcutaneous tissue of the left cheek. Examination of a tissue sample obtained via biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, with positive staining observed using PAS and GMS methods. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis. GMS positive confirms this.

It is fungal infection which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs. 

Other Options:

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: This is a term historically used to describe aggressive midline facial granulomatous diseases, often linked to conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). It does not fit the biopsy findings or clinical scenario described here.

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Although the biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, the positive PAS and GMS staining suggests a fungal etiology, which is characteristic of Phycomycosis.

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: This is associated with IgG4-related disease, which presents with different clinical and histopathological findings, not typically involving PAS and GMS positive fungal elements.

Educational Objective:

Phycomycosis should be considered in patients with a history of trauma, swelling, and positive fungal stains (PAS and GMS), particularly if they have underlying conditions like diabetes or immunosuppression.

questions.text:
Mark the correct statement/s about Inner and Outer hair cells. (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses
  2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells
  3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for movement of tectorial membrane
  4. Inner hair cells are in single row and modulate function of outer hair cells
  5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 5 are correct 

This choice correctly identifies that inner hair cells transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in multiple rows and aid in the functionality related to cochlear amplification, and that there is a numerical dominance of outer hair cells compared to inner hair cells. 

The correct statements regarding the roles and arrangements of inner and outer hair cells within the cochlea, based on the options given, are as follows:

1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses: This statement is correct. Inner hair cells are primarily responsible for transmitting auditory signals to the brain. They are fewer in number compared to outer hair cells and are arranged in a single row along the length of the cochlea.

2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate the function of inner hair cells: This is correct. Outer hair cells are indeed arranged in 3-4 rows. They play a crucial role in amplifying and fine-tuning the vibrations within the cochlea through their motility, which affects how the inner hair cells respond to sound. 

5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1: This statement is  correct. There are significantly more outer hair cells than inner hair cells, typically at a ratio close to 3:1, reflecting their arrangement in multiple rows compared to the single row of inner hair cells.

Other Options:

3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for the movement of the tectorial membrane: This statement is incorrect. Outer hair cells do contribute to the movement of the tectorial membrane through their motility and changes in length, but it's more accurate to say they influence the fluid mechanics around the inner hair cells, affecting how the tectorial membrane interacts with them.

4. Inner hair cells are in a single row and modulate function of outer hair cells: This statement is incorrect. Inner hair cells do not modulate the function of outer hair cells; rather, they function primarily as sensory transducers sending information to the brain.

Educational Objective: 

The correct statements about inner and outer hair cells are that inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and help modulate cochlear mechanics, and the ratio of outer to inner hair cells is about 3:1.

choices.text: It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases
It shows Ad type of curve

questions.text: A patient has otitis media with effusion. Which of the following is wrong?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It shows Ad type of curve

 

Otitis media with effusion (OME) is a condition characterized by the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs or symptoms of acute ear infection. The incorrect statement regarding it is, It shows Ad type of curve. This statement is incorrect. OME typically shows a B type of tympanogram curve. A B type curve indicates the presence of middle ear fluid. An Ad type curve is associated with ossicular discontinuity, which is not related to OME.

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bilateral: Can be true but not mandatory; OME can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Option B. It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases: True, as the condition often resolves with the resolution of the underlying URTI.

 

Option C. It is associated with cold: True, as URTI and colds can lead to Eustachian tube dysfunction and subsequent fluid accumulation in the middle ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otitis media with effusion shows a B type of tympanogram curve, not an Ad type curve.

questions.text: Under which of the following, Rhinosporidium seeberi is classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aquatic Protistan protozoa

 

RHINOSPORIDIOSIS

 

  • Causative organism: Rhinosporidium Seeberi (earlier considered fungus, now classified under protozoa)
  • Life cycle: 3 stages: Trophic, Sporangium formation, Endospore production.
  • Spread by contaminated water of ponds, seen commonly in coastal areas
  • Appearance: leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple (strawberry), bleeds on touch.
  • Complaints: Blood tinged nasal discharge & stuffiness
  • Diagnosis by biopsy (spores bursting through chitinous wall of sporangia)
  • Treatment: Diathermy excision with base cauterization ± Dapsone

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Although previously considered a fungus, current classifications based on molecular analysis place Rhinosporidium seeberi under protozoa.

 

Option B: Viruses are infectious agents that replicate inside the living cells of organisms which is not a characteristic of Rhinosporidium seeberi.

 

Option D: Bacteria are single-celled microorganisms with simple internal structures, quite distinct from the complex life cycle and morphology of Rhinosporidium seeberi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidium seeberi, responsible for rhinosporidiosis, is classified as an aquatic Protistan protozoa, not a fungus, highlighting the importance of accurate organism classification in understanding transmission and management of infections.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. A histology image is shown below. What can be the diagnosis for this patient?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schwannoma

 

The given clinical scenario and histology image showing Verocay bodies are suggestive of Schwannoma /Acoustic neuroma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibroma is a benign tumor that develops along nerve cells. Histology image shows wreath like multinucleated giant cells.

 

 

Option B. Leiomyoma on histology shows well-differentiated, regular, spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with hyalinization.

 

 

Option D. Rhabdomyoma on microscopy shows enlarged myocytes with abundant glycogen. Post-processing, glycogen content gets reduced and look like thin strands.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannoma is a benign tumor often associated with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, diagnosed via characteristic histological patterns and confirmed with MRI. It requires careful management, sometimes involving advanced surgical techniques such as Gamma Knife surgery.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion 

 

The presentation of a child with a type B tympanometry curve indicates the likelihood of serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy as the underlying cause.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grommet insertion: While this can relieve middle ear effusion, it does not address the underlying adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion: Similar to grommet insertion alone, this option does not address the root cause of adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option D. Myringotomy: This procedure involves making an incision in the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure or drain fluid but does not address the cause or provide a lasting solution like adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is the most appropriate management for a child presenting with serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy, addressing both the immediate symptoms and underlying cause.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective tests for hearing do not require the active cooperation or response from the patient and are thus particularly useful in non-cooperative subjects such as young children or those who might simulate hearing loss.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system. It evaluates the mobility of the eardrum (tympanic membrane) and the conduction bones of the middle ear, providing useful information about middle ear pressure and fluid presence.

 

Other Option:

 

3. PTA (pure tone audiometry): This is a subjective test as it relies on the patient's response to pure tone stimuli. It is not included as an objective test because it requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. Subjective tests such as PTA, tuning fork tests, and speech audiometry depend on patient interaction and are susceptible to voluntary or involuntary response errors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective hearing tests like BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic information without the need for patient interaction, distinguishing them from subjective tests like Pure Tone Audiometry which rely on patient responses.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient arrives at the clinic with complaints of nasal obstruction on the right side and sporadic occurrences of blood-stained nasal discharge. The CT scan results are depicted in the image provided. What might be the potential underlying reason for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inverted Papilloma

 

An elderly patient with unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis and a mass visible points to a diagnosis of Inverted Papilloma.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Maxillary carcinoma arises from maxillary sinus lining and presents with facial paresthesia, lacrimation and pain.

 

 

Option C. Esthesioneuroblastoma/ Olfactory neuroblastomas are tumors arising from the basal layer of the olfactory epithelium in the superior recess of the nasal cavity. They usually present as a soft tissue mass in the superior olfactory recess involving the anterior and middle ethmoid air-cells on one side and extending through the cribriform plate into the anterior cranial fossa.

 

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is seen exclusively in males. Commonly presents with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted Papilloma should be considered when an elderly patient presents with unilateral nasal symptoms and imaging reveals a mass, especially when the presentation includes epistaxis and nasal obstruction without the severe pain or neurological symptoms that might suggest a more malignant etiology.

questions.text: What is absent in a case of otitis media among the options provided? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Battle's sign

 

Battle's sign, characterized by ecchymosis (bruising) over the mastoid process, is typically indicative of a basilar skull fracture, specifically fractures involving the temporal bone. It is not associated with otitis media, which is an infection or inflammation of the middle ear.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: This abscess is a serious complication of otitis media. It occurs when the infection spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, leading to a collection of pus.

Option B. Griesinger's sign: This sign is associated with lateral sinus thrombosis, a rare but severe complication of otitis media and mastoiditis. It involves tenderness and swelling behind the ear and along the mastoid bone.

Option D. Delta sign: Also related to lateral sinus thrombosis, the Delta sign typically appears on contrast-enhanced imaging studies as a NON enhancement at thrombosed area of sinus, a complication arising from otitis media.

Educational Objective:

 

While otitis media can lead to various complications, including Bezold abscess and lateral sinus thrombosis (indicated by Griesinger’s sign and Delta sign), Battle's sign is not associated with this condition. Instead, Battle's sign should prompt an evaluation for temporal bone fractures, emphasizing the importance of distinguishing between signs of infection and trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 87, 93, 507

questions.text: A metal factory worker suffers from noise-induced hearing loss. Which of the following structures will be affected? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Outer hair cells

 

  • Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL) causes damage to outer hair cells.
  • NIHL Hearing loss, in this case, is due to chronic exposure.
  • It can be of two types
     
    1. Temporary threshold shift (TTS). The hearing is impaired immediately after exposure to noise but recovers after an interval of a few minutes to a few hours even up to 2 weeks
    2. Permanent threshold shift (PTS). The hearing impairment is permanent and does not recover at all.

 

The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch, at 4 kHz, both for air and bone conduction. This is referred to as acoustic dip or Boiler's notch.

 

 

The damage caused by noise trauma depends on several factors:

 

  1. Frequency of noise. A frequency of 2000–3000 Hz causes more damage than lower or higher frequencies.
  2. Intensity and duration of noise. As the intensity increases, permissible time for exposure is reduced.
  3. Continuous noise is more harmful.
  4. Susceptibility of the individual. Degree of TTS and PTS varies in different individuals.
  5. Pre-existing ear disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crista ampullaris: This structure is located within the semicircular canals of the inner ear and is primarily involved in sensing rotational movements of the head, not in hearing. Thus, it is not typically affected by noise-induced hearing loss.

 

Option B. Macula: Found in the utricle and saccule of the vestibular system, the macula detects linear accelerations and head tilts but is not directly involved in the auditory response to sound waves.

 

Option C. Cupola: The cupola is a gelatin-like structure in the vestibular system's semicircular canals that responds to changes in head position. Like the crista ampullaris, it is unrelated to the hearing process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noise-induced hearing loss specifically damages the outer hair cells in the cochlea, leading to hearing impairment.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 36, 37

questions.text:
What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image?

(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
✅ Correct Answer: B. Grade 2

📸 Image Analysis:

The otoscopic image shows a retracted pars tensa where deeper middle ear structures like the long process of the incus and incudostapedial joint are visible. The lateral process of the malleus is prominently seen, and the tympanic membrane appears pulled medially, but it is not adherent to the promontory, and air is still visible in the middle ear. This presentation is typical of Grade 2 retraction.

🔍 Explanation of Options:

Option A: Grade 1

In Grade 1 pars tensa retraction, there is only mild inward retraction. The cone of light is lost, the fibrous annulus appears more prominent, and the handle of the malleus becomes more medialized. Importantly, there is no contact with the ossicles, and ossicular landmarks like the incus are not visible. This does not match the findings seen in the image.

 

Option B: Grade 2

Grade 2 retraction is more severe than Grade 1, and the pars tensa is retracted to the extent that it touches the long process of the incus. Deeper structures like the incudostapedial joint, round window niche, and even the horizontal facial canal may be visible. The tympanic membrane still retains some mobility and is not adherent to the promontory. This fits the otoscopic image exactly, where ossicular structures are seen but no signs of complete adhesion are present.

 

Option C: Grade 3

In Grade 3 retraction, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and becomes adherent to the promontory, forming what is called an atelectatic membrane. Although some air may still remain in the middle ear, the drum is essentially collapsed onto the medial wall. This condition is more advanced than what is seen in the current image.

 

Option D: Grade 4

This is the most severe stage where the entire tympanic membrane is stuck to the promontory, and there is complete loss of middle ear aeration. It often leads to adhesive otitis media, and ossicular erosion (such as necrosis of the incus) may occur. This is clearly not the case here, as ossicles are intact and the membrane is not fully adherent.

🧠 Educational Objective:

Grade 2 pars tensa retraction is identified when the tympanic membrane retracts to touch the long process of the incus without adhering to the promontory, often revealing middle ear ossicles such as the incudostapedial joint.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 - 1 - 3 - 4 - 5

 

The auditory pathway is the sequence of neural structures that sound information travels through from the ear to the brain for processing. The correct sequence from the initial sensory input at the ear to the higher centers of the brain is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion : Contains the cell bodies of the auditory nerve fibers. These neurons receive mechanical sound vibrations converted into electrical signals by the hair cells of the cochlea.

 

1. Cochlear nucleus : The first brainstem nucleus where auditory nerve fibers synapse. This nucleus begins the central processing of auditory information.

 

3. Superior olivary nucleus : Receives inputs from both cochlear nuclei and is involved in binaural cues for sound localization.

 

4. Inferior colliculus : A midbrain nucleus that acts as a major relay and integration point for auditory information.

 

5. Medial geniculate body : Part of the thalamus that acts as the final relay station for auditory information being sent to the auditory cortex in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). 
    1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
    2. Cochlear Nucleus
    3. Superior Olivary nucleus
    4. Lateral lemniscus
    5. Inferior colliculus
    6. Medial geniculate body
    7. Auditory cortex
  • The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

questions.text: All of the following are major diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal sinusitis except? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive fungal culture

 

A positive fungal culture is a minor diagnostic criterion for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

 

This classification was detailed by Bent and Kuhn, who established criteria based on their findings of several clinical features important for the diagnosis of AFRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of nasal polyps: Polyps are a common and significant finding in AFRS, often contributing to the blockage and symptoms of sinusitis.

 

Option B. Eosinophilic mucin: A hallmark of AFRS, this refers to thick, peanut butter-like mucin with eosinophils.

 

Option C. Characteristic CT findings: These include hyperdense areas within the sinuses, which are indicative of fungal involvement and mucin accumulation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bent and Kuhn described a diagnostic criterion for AFRS. They found 11 important clinical features, 5 of which were termed major criteria and the remaining 6 features as minor criteria. These criteria includes:

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, Volume 1, Page No. 1049

choices.text: Point of maximum tension in a fracture
Collagen and elastin lines in stab injury

questions.text: What are Kraissl’s lines?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Relaxed tension lines in skin

 

Kraissl’s lines, also known as relaxed skin tension lines (RSTLs), are lines on the skin that indicate the natural orientation of the skin under minimal or no tension. They are used in surgical planning, particularly in cosmetic surgery, to guide incisions so that they heal with the least visible scars. Kraissl’s lines differ from Langer's lines, which also describe lines of skin tension but are based on the alignment of collagen fibers within the dermis and are typically used to predict surgical wound healing outcomes.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point of maximum tension in a fracture: Refers to the area where the mechanical stress is greatest on a broken bone, unrelated to skin tension lines.

 

Option C. Collagen and elastin lines in stab injury: Would refer to the orientation of these fibers in response to a penetrating trauma, which is not what Kraissl’s lines describe.

 

Option D. Point of tension in hanging: Refers to the mechanical stress points exerted during a hanging, specifically on the neck, which has no relation to the relaxed skin tension lines described by Kraissl.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Kraissl’s lines are crucial for surgical incision planning to ensure scars are minimally visible following healing, highlighting the importance of understanding skin tension dynamics in medical procedures.

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.text: During the process of conducting a caloric test, what kind of nystagmus should one anticipate when using cold water irrigation?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side

 

In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side.

 

Fitzgerald-Hallpike test or bithermal caloric test procedure:

 

  • Patient is made to lie supine with the head tilted 30° forward so that the horizontal canal is vertical.

 

 

  • Irrigation stimulates the lateral/ horizontal semicircular canal which produces horizontal nystagmus.
  • Cold water induces nystagmus to the opposite side and warm water to the same side (remember mnemonic COWS: cold-opposite, warm-same)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side: This option is incorrect for cold water irrigation. Cold water causes the fluid in the horizontal semicircular canal to move in a way that induces nystagmus towards the opposite side, not the same side.

 

Option B. Vertical nystagmus towards the same side and Option D. Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side: Vertical nystagmus does not occur in caloric testing, as this test specifically stimulates the horizontal semicircular canal, inducing horizontal nystagmus. Vertical nystagmus is generally associated with different pathologies and is not a result of standard caloric testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The caloric test, particularly when using cold water, is designed to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal, resulting in horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side. This test is critical for evaluating unilateral weaknesses in the vestibular system and helps in diagnosing conditions affecting balance and spatial orientation.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, page No. 45

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors and moving towards the cortex: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Auditory Cortex
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Cochlear Nucleus
  4. Lateral leminiscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Olivary complex
  7. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-3-6-4-5-7-1

 

The correct sequence of structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors (cochlea) and moving towards the auditory cortex, is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion: The auditory nerve fibers originate here.

 

3. Cochlear Nucleus: The auditory nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

6. Olivary complex: After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary complex.

 

4. Lateral lemniscus: From the superior olivary complex, the auditory signals travel via the lateral lemniscus.

 

5. Inferior colliculus: The lateral lemniscus projects to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

7. Medial geniculate body: The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

1. Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals reach the auditory cortex (Area 41) in the temporal lobe for processing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

AUDITORY PATHWAY

 

E – Eighth nerve

 

C – Cochlear nucleus

 

O – Olivary complex (superior)

 

L – Lateral lemniscus

 

I – Inferior colliculus

 

M – Medial geniculate body

 

A – Auditory cortex

questions.text: The radiograph presented below has been taken to enhance the evaluation of the frontal sinus. What is the widely used term for this particular perspective?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caldwell view

 

  • The above X ray shows the Caldwell view in which the frontal sinus is best seen.
  • Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is taken with nose and forehead touching the film and X-ray beam is projected 15–20° caudally.
  • Structures seen are:
    1. Frontal sinuses (Best Visualization).
    2. Ethmoid sinuses.
    3. Maxillary sinuses.
    4. Frontal process of zygoma and zygomatic process of frontal bone.
    5. Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea.
    6. Superior orbital fissure.
    7. Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water's view: Primarily used for examining the maxillary sinuses and can also show the frontal sinuses but with less clarity than the Caldwell view.

 

Option C. Pierre's view: This is not a standard term in radiographic terminology.

 

Option D. Towne's view: Used to visualize the occipital bone and foramen magnum, not typically used for sinus examination.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A person presents with a tongue ulcer persisting for 3 months. Upon examination, a lesion measuring 3.5 cm x 2.5 cm is observed, accompanied by an 8 mm area of hardened tissue. No lymph node enlargement is detected. According to the 8th AJCC guidelines, what stage does this lesion correspond to? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage II

 

In the given case can be classified as T2N0M0 as per AJCC 2002 as the size of the lesion is between 2-4 cm (T2) with no nodal (N0) or distant metastasis (M0) and that will come under Stage II disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage I: This stage would be applicable for T1 tumors, which are 2 cm or less in greatest dimension, and does not fit the description of the lesion presented.

 

Option C. Stage III: This stage would involve either T3 tumors, which are greater than 4 cm, or any T1-T3 tumors with N1 lymph node involvement, neither of which applies to this case.

 

Option D. Stage IV: This stage is reserved for more advanced disease involving T4 tumors, any tumor with N2 or N3 lymph node involvement, or distant metastasis (M1), which are not applicable in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 256

questions.text: Please identify the retractor depicted in the image below:(INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mollison's mastoid retractor

 

  • The instrument shown in the above image is Mollison's mastoid retractor.
  • It is used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Joll's retractor is used in thyroid surgery. It is self-retaining retractor.

 

 

Option B. Perkins retractor is used to open small incisions with minimal damage to surrounding tissues.

 

 

Option D. Langenbeck retractor is used to hold back, edges of incisions, tissue or organs

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mollison's Mastoid retractor is specifically tailored for ear surgeries, particularly mastoidectomy, where precise and sustained retraction of soft tissues is crucial. Understanding the specific applications and features of various retractors enhances surgical efficiency and safety.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given CT image. (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumatised superior turbinate

 

The superior turbinates form one of the three pairs of conchae in the nose and represent part of the labyrinth of the ethmoid bone, arising as bony projections from its posterior surface.

 

The air passage between the superior nasal concha and the lateral nasal wall is known as the superior meatus and forms part of the nasal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concha bullosa is a pneumatized middle turbinate.

 

 

Option C. Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell/ infraorbital ethmoidal air cells are ethmoid air cells located lateral to the maxillo-ethmoidal suture along the inferomedial orbital floor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumatisation of the superior turbinate, indicates the presence of air spaces within the turbinates, which can have implications for nasal physiology and potential sinus pathologies.

questions.text: Carhart notch is seen in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Otosclerosis

 

Carhart's notch is a characteristic audiometric finding in otosclerosis where there is a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz (2 kHz) on pure tone audiometry. In otosclerosis, there is irregular spongy bone deposition in the anterior part of footplate and adjacent oval window (fissula ante fenestram), which impedes sound conduction and causes conductive hearing loss. When plotting an audiogram, the bone conduction curve shows this specific notch or dip at 2000 Hz, while the air conduction curve remains affected throughout, showing the conductive hearing loss pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sudden SNHL: Sudden sensorineural hearing loss shows a sudden drop in both air and bone conduction curves across all frequencies without any specific notch pattern at 2000 Hz.

 

Option C. Meniere's disease: In Meniere's disease, the audiogram typically shows a low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss with an up-sloping curve. There is no specific notch at 2000 Hz.

 

 

Option D. Acoustic neuroma: Acoustic neuroma typically shows a trough-shaped or cookie-bite audiogram pattern affecting the middle frequencies, but does not show the specific Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carhart's notch is a characteristic dip at 2000 Hz on the bone conduction curve in pure tone audiometry, specifically seen in otosclerosis.

 

Important points to remember on otoselerosis:

 

  • Most common site - Fissula ante fenestrum
  • Most common type- Stapedial
  • Other 2 type -Cochlear, Histologic
  • Clinical presentation - Hearing impairment
  • Paracusis willisii (hears better in noisy surroundngs)
  • Otoscopy - Intract tympanic membrane
  • Schwarts sign - Seen in active lesions only, reddish hue seen on promontory through intact TM
  • Tunning fork tests - Rinne negative, Weber to poorer ear → conductive loss
  • Pure tone audiometry -Dip at 2000Hz on BC curve (Carhart's notch)
  • Treatment of choice - Surgery (Stapedotomy > Stapedectomy)
  • Other treatments - NaF, Hearing aid for those not fit for surgery.

questions.text: A patient complains that he feels like the room is spinning when he gets up from lying down or turning his head. He has no history of loss of consciousness. Which of the following could be the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).
  • BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals (otoconia) usually dislodged from the utricle. These otoconia will enter the semicircular canal and will cause change in the density of the endolymphatic fluid as well as they will inadvertently touch the cupula and cause unnecessary stimulation of the hair cells in cristae.
  • Epley's maneuver is performed to reposition the crystals into the utricle from the semicircular canals. This is only a temporary cure and there is a high rate of recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meniere's disease: Presents with recurrent spontaneous vertigo episodes lasting for hours associated by aural fullness, tinnitus and hearing loss.

 

Option C. Labyrinthitis: Presents with severe, sudden-onset, spontaneous vertigo which is continuous and associated with hearing loss, nausea and vomiting.

 

Option D. Syncope is defined as a transient, self-limited loss of consciousness with an inability to maintain postural tone that is followed by spontaneous recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otto veraguth folds

Allergic rhinitis is a condition characterized by symptoms such as sneezing, nasal congestion, runny nose, and itchy eyes. These symptoms can lead to several physical signs due to chronic inflammation and repetitive actions like rubbing the nose and eyes. However we do not see Otto Veraguth folds in Allergic Rhinitis.

 Also known as Veraguth folds, these are small creases on the upper eyelid and are not related to allergic rhinitis. They are typically associated with individuals suffering from depression, not allergic conditions.

Other Options:

Option A. Allergic Shiners: Commonly seen in allergic rhinitis due to venous congestion under the eyes.

Option B. Allergic Salute: A habitual action in allergic rhinitis leading to a nasal crease.

Option D. Dennis Morgan Lines: Found in chronic allergic conditions due to persistent inflammation and edema, including allergic rhinitis.

Educational Objective: 

Otto Veraguth folds are not associated with allergic rhinitis but are more commonly seen in individuals with depression.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image. (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenoid facies

 

The above given image shows adenoid facies. The characteristic features are visible which are: -

 

  • Elongated face with dull expression
  • Open mouth
  • Hitched up upper lip
  • Prominent upper teeth, which appear crowded
  • High arched hard palate
  • Pinched-in nose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goldenhar syndrome: Typically presents with abnormalities of the eye, ear, and spine, none of which are visible in this image.

 

Option C. Horse facies: Characterized by an elongated face with prominent jaw structures, which does not match the features in the image.

 

Option D. Frog facies: Often includes a wide mouth and bulging eyes, which are not present in this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoid facies can be recognized by characteristic features such as elongated face, open mouth posture due to nasal obstruction, hitched up upper lip revealing crowded upper teeth, and a pinched-in nose. It's associated with chronic adenoid hypertrophy, impacting the facial structure and respiratory function.

choices.text: It may lead to pugilistic ear
It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space
All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented at the hospital with a reported history of ear trauma. Upon examination, there was observed swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Resolves spontaneously

 

The condition depicted in the image is perichondrial hematoma, commonly resulting from blunt trauma to the ear. This condition does not resolve spontaneously and requires medical intervention to prevent complications such as infection or the permanent deformity known as cauliflower ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It may lead to pugilistic ear: This is true. If untreated, the hematoma can lead to fibrosis and calcification, causing a deformity known as cauliflower ear or pugilistic ear.

 

Option B. It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: True. The swelling and discoloration are due to blood accumulating in the perichondrial space, which separates the ear cartilage from the overlying skin.

 

Option D. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics: This is considered a good practice to prevent infection, especially since the ear's vascular supply is compromised, increasing the risk of perichondritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perichondrial hematoma does not resolve on its own and requires prompt medical treatment to prevent complications like infection and the formation of cauliflower ear. Management typically involves aspiration of the hematoma, application of a pressure dressing to maintain ear contour, and administration of prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection.

questions.text: The image given shows a patient who has undergone total laryngectomy due to laryngeal cancer. Identify the method of voice generation for this patient, as depicted in the provided image.(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tracheoesophageal prosthesis

 

The voice production modality depicted in the image is tracheoesophageal voice prosthesis.

 

The extended air from the trachea is diverted to the esophagus through a device that connects the trachea and esophagus in tracheoesophageal prosthesis. It also has a one-way valve that keeps food from entering into the trachea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrolarynx: Is a vibrating instrument that emits a low-pitched sound in the hypopharynx. The palate, tongue, and teeth then articulate it.

 

Option B. Chicago implant: Is a type of hearing aid.

 

Option D. Esophageal speech: The patient is trained to swallow air and slowly release it into the pharynx. 6-10 words can be spoken in a rough manner before re-swallowing the air.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a common and effective method for voice restoration following total laryngectomy. It relies on a surgically implanted device that directs air into the esophagus where vibrations are created for speech, significantly enhancing the quality of life for patients who have lost their natural voice box.

questions.text: What is the site of drainage of the marked structure? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sphenoethmoidal recess

 

The identified anatomical feature corresponds to the sphenoid sinus, which effectively empties into the Sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior meatus: This meatus drains the posterior ethmoid sinus.

 

Option B. Middle meatus: The middle meatus is the drainage site for several other sinuses, including the frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, and anterior ethmoid sinus. It is the most common drainage site for these sinuses, but not for the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option C. Inferior meatus: This meatus primarily serves as the drainage site for the nasolacrimal duct, which is responsible for draining tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity. It does not play a role in draining any of the paranasal sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 209

questions.text: What are the air cells located at the anterior most part of the anterior ethmoidal sinus called?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Agger nasi

 

The Agger nasi cells are the anterior-most air cells of the anterior ethmoid air cells. They are situated just above the attachment of the middle turbinate, making them critical landmarks in sinus surgery due to their proximity to the frontal sinus drainage pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulla ethmoidalis largest air cells in ethmoidal air sinus

 

Option B. Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell. They are significant due to their proximity to the optic nerve and the sphenoid sinus, posing a risk during sinus surgery.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell/ infraorbital ethmoidal air cells are ethmoid air cells located lateral to the maxillo-ethmoidal suture along the inferomedial orbital floor. Haller cells can impact the drainage of the maxillary sinus and are important to consider in imaging and surgical planning for sinus issues.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Agger nasi is the anterior-most air cells of anterior ethmoid air cells.
  • Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest air cells in ethmoidal air sinus
  • Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cells
  • Haller cells are ethmoid air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit and can affect the integrity and drainage of the maxillary sinus

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 152, 153

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of hearing loss and can understand only shouted or amplified speech. What would be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe hearing loss

Severe hearing loss means that individuals cannot hear most conversations. They typically only hear very loud sounds, such as a raised voice or sounds above 61 to 80 dB. They may not understand speech at normal levels and usually require powerful hearing aids or cochlear implants to assist their hearing. These individuals may rely more on lip reading or sign language.

Other Options:

Option A. Mild hearing loss: Individuals with mild hearing loss typically have difficulty understanding speech, especially in noisy situations. The hearing loss ranges between 26 and 40 decibels (dB). They can usually hear well in one-to-one conversations and might only struggle in noisier environments.

Option B. Moderate hearing loss: With moderate hearing loss, individuals have difficulty understanding regular speech, even at close distances. The hearing loss is between 41 and 60 dB. They often require some form of hearing assistance for daily activities and may benefit significantly from hearing aids.

Option D. Profound hearing loss: Profound hearing loss indicates that individuals cannot hear any speech and only very loud sounds exceeding 81 dB, such as that from heavy machinery or loud horns. Conversational speech is not audible at all. Persons with profound hearing loss rely on visual communication methods like sign language and may be candidates for cochlear implants.

Educational Objective: 

The case scenario described above points towards Severe hearing loss in the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trismus

 

  • Trismus is not a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space.
  • Parapharyngeal space is divided into 2 compartments by styloid process & its attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vocal cord palsy: This could manifest due to involvement of the cranial nerves (CN IX, X, XI, XII) that are located in the post-styloid compartment. CN X (vagus nerve) palsy particularly can lead to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option C. Parotid swelling: Swelling in this region may occur as the post-styloid compartment is adjacent to the parotid gland and includes inflammatory processes that might extend into the parotid space.

 

Option D. Horner's syndrome: This syndrome may appear if the sympathetic chain, which runs through the post-styloid compartment, is affected by an infection or its related inflammatory processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presentation in a post-styloid abscess:

 

Bulge behind posterior tonsillar pillar.

 

  • Since post styloid compartment contains CN IX, X, XI, XII, their palsies may be seen.
  • Sympathetic chain involvement in this compartment will cause Horner's syndrome.
  • Swelling of the parotid region
  • No trismus or minimal trismus
  • General Symptoms - Fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis (due to spasm of prevertebral muscles) and signs of toxemia

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Contrast-enhanced CT scan neck – for extent of a lesion.
  • Magnetic resonance arteriography is useful if thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or aneurysm of the internal carotid artery is suspected.

 

Treatment

 

  • IV antibiotics with aerobic and anaerobic cover
  • Incision and drainage of abscess

questions.text: Which of the following is not ligated for the control of epistaxis?(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal carotid artery

 

Internal carotid artery is not ligated in epistaxis control due to high percentage of cerebral complications and high mortality.

 

Ligation of the following arteries is done in epistaxis control:

 

  • Trans nasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine artery - TESPAL
  • If not controlled, maxillary artery ligation
  • If still not controlled, external carotid artery ligation
  • In case, the bleeding site is superior to the level of middle turbinate, then anterior and posterior ethmoidal vessels should be ligated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior ethmoidal artery: This artery may be ligated if the bleeding site is superior to the level of the middle turbinate, as it is one of the contributing vessels to the nasal cavity that might be involved in epistaxis.

 

Option C. Maxillary artery: Ligation of the maxillary artery is considered if epistaxis is not controlled by less invasive methods such as the ligation of the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Option D. External carotid artery: As a last resort, if bleeding persists despite ligation of more specific branches, ligation of the external carotid artery may be performed to control severe epistaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of severe epistaxis, it is critical to understand the hierarchy of arterial ligation, starting with the least risky options. The internal carotid artery should never be ligated due to its vital role in cerebral blood supply, highlighting the importance of targeted vascular control in surgical interventions to minimize complications.

questions.text: A male cattle breeder from South India presents with frank, intermittent epistaxis. The description of the nasal examination is provided below. A biopsy was conducted, and the histopathological examination findings are depicted as presented below. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

The given clinical scenario, image showing a patient with polypoidal mass and HPE image revealing sporangium, points to a diagnosis of Rhinosporidiosis.

RHINOSPORIDIOSIS 

  • Causative organism: Rhinosporidium Seeberi (earlier considered fungus, now classified under protozoa)

  • Life cycle: 3 stages: Trophic, Sporangium formation, Endospore production.

  • Spread by contaminated water of ponds, seen commonly in coastal areas

  • Appearance: leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple (strawberry), bleeds on touch.

  • Complaints: Blood tinged nasal discharge & stuffiness

  • Diagnosis by biopsy (spores bursting through chitinous wall of sporangia)

  • Treatment: Diathermy excision with base cauterization ± Dapsone

Other Options:

Option A. Nasal polyp: Typically presents as a non-neoplastic mass, usually bilateral and associated with conditions like chronic rhinosinusitis. They do not bleed on touch and do not have the characteristic histopathological findings seen in Rhinosporidiosis.

Option C. Hemangioma: Vascular tumors that appear as reddish-blue lesions, which are compressible and usually do not present with the same histopathological features as Rhinosporidiosis.

Option D. Rhinophyma: A severe form of rosacea resulting in a large, bulbous, and red nose. It is not associated with nasal bleeding or the histopathological findings presented in this case.

Educational Objective:

Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients presenting with polypoidal nasal masses, especially if there is a history of exposure to contaminated water. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy revealing characteristic sporangia, and treatment involves surgical excision with cauterization.

choices.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of these options is not a division originating from the external carotid artery within Kiesselbach's plexus? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery which in turn is a branch of internal carotid artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphenopalatine artery: This artery is correctly identified as a branch of the maxillary artery, which itself is a major branch of the external carotid artery. It contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus by providing the septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Option C. Greater palatine artery: Also a branch of the maxillary artery, the septal branch of the greater palatine artery participates in forming Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Option D. Septal branch of superior labial artery: This artery, a branch of the facial artery (which originates from the external carotid artery), is part of the blood supply to Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ARTERIAL SUPPLY OF THE NOSE:

 

Internal carotid system -

 

  • Branches of ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

 

External Carotid System –

 

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).

 

KIESSELBACH'S PLEXUS -

 

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of greater palatine

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: Which of these structures are retained during radical neck dissection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sublingual gland

 

In a radical neck dissection, the aim is to remove extensive lymphatic tissue potentially involved with malignancies, but the procedure generally spares certain non-lymphatic structures unless directly involved by the tumor. The sublingual gland, which is located under the floor of the mouth, is not typically removed during a radical neck dissection because it is not within the field of the lymph node groups that are typically excised. This gland remains intact unless the specific tumor pathology dictates otherwise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tail of parotid: The tail of the parotid may be removed if it is involved with the tumor or if the dissection needs to be extended to ensure comprehensive removal of cancerous tissues.

 

Option C. Submandibular gland: This gland is typically removed during radical neck dissections because it lies within the Level I lymph nodes, which are included in the dissection.

 

Option D. Level 2b lymph nodes: These are generally removed in a radical neck dissection, which traditionally includes the removal of lymph nodes from Levels I to V.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition Page No. 442; Stell and Maran 5th edition Page No. 710

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from the nose, nasal obstruction and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red polypoidal mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination and given histopathological image what would be the diagnosis of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidiosis

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by the aquatic organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It primarily affects mucous membranes, especially in the nasal passages but also the eyes, ears, and occasionally other areas. Patients typically present with polypoidal masses in the nasal area that can cause bleeding, nasal obstruction, and respiratory difficulty. It is commonly associated with exposure to stagnant water.

Histopathology: Characteristic findings include large, thick-walled sporangia containing numerous endospores, as observed in the provided histopathological image.

Other Options: 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma

Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that commonly appears on sun-exposed areas but can occasionally occur near the nasal region. It typically presents as a nodular lesion with a pearly edge and may have telangiectasias but lacks the distinct histopathology of sporangia with endospores.

Histopathology: Microscopically, it shows nests of basaloid cells with palisading nuclei at the periphery.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting the respiratory tract. It leads to the formation of hard, sclerotic nodules and masses mainly in the nasal passages.

Histopathology: It is characterized by the presence of Mikulicz cells, which are large foam cells containing the bacteria, and a background of chronic inflammatory cells.

Option D. Lupus Vulgaris

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting typically on the skin with reddish-brown nodules and plaques that can ulcerate over time. It rarely affects the nasal area directly unless there is disseminated cutaneous involvement.

Histopathology: Shows granulomatous inflammation with caseating necrosis typical of tuberculosis.

Educational Objective:
