Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients with nasal masses who have a history of contact with stagnant water bodies, presenting with the characteristic polypoidal mass and sporangia on histopathology.

questions.text: The provided picture shows a patient who has undergone mastoidectomy. Identify the lateral semicircular canal in the image. (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

In the given image of a post-mastoidectomy surgical field, label A corresponds to the lateral semicircular canal. The lateral semicircular canal is a crucial component of the inner ear's vestibular system, involved in maintaining balance and spatial orientation. It can be identified by its specific location relative to other anatomical landmarks visible in the image, such as the tympanic bone, mastoid tip, and the spine of Henle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: This label points to the posterior semicircular canal, which is a bony protrusion in the mastoid portion of the temporal bone, serving as an important landmark during mastoid surgery.

 

Option C: This indicates the sigmoid sinus, a dural venous sinus within the skull, lying beneath the cranial bone and above the structures of the middle and inner ear.

 

Option D: Labelled as the Tegmen, which is part of the temporal bone that forms the roof over the middle ear and mastoid antrum, shielding these structures from the intracranial contents.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The lateral semicircular canal, identified at label A, is part of the vestibular system, crucial for balance and orientation.

questions.text: What test is not used for testing olfaction? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arnold stick test

 

The Arnold stick test is not a recognized method for assessing olfaction. The name does not correspond with standard or commonly used olfactory tests, which typically involve the identification or differentiation of specific odors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smell Diskettes: These are used in screening tests for olfaction, where reusable diskettes are impregnated with different odorants. Participants are asked to identify scents from a list, often aided by illustrative questionnaires.

Option C. UPSIT: The University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test is a widely recognized and comprehensive olfactory test. It is self-administered and involves scratching odor-impregnated booklets to release smells, which the test-taker must then identify.

Option D. CC-SIT: The Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test, a shorter form of the UPSIT, consists of 12 items and is designed for quick administration, making it practical for use in diverse populations and clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tests used for olfaction are as follows:

 

  1. Smell diskettes are used as a screening test for olfaction. Reusable diskettes are used with the application of 8 different odorants. A questionnaire with illustrations is used to score the patient.
  2. University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) is a commercially available, self-administered test used to assess the function of an individual's olfactory system via smell identification. It uses microencapsulated odorants, which are released on scratching standardized odor-impregnated test booklets.
  3. The 12-item version of UPSIT, also known as the Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test (CC-SIT), is useful for quantifying smell loss when less time is available. This test serves as a means to reliably assess olfactory function in less than 5 minutes.
  4. The Sniffin' Sticks test is a new test of nasal chemosensory performance based on pen-like odor-dispensing devices. Semi-objective assessment of the patient's olfactory performance by means of 3 subtests: threshold test, identification test and discrimination test.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 2, Page No. 1233

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient arrives at the OPD with a concern about her ability to perceive speech sounds while struggling to comprehend the actual words being spoken. Her Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) and Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) results show discrepancies, as the PTA is relatively within the normal range. However, her mid-latency and cortical responses are both non-existent. What probable diagnosis can be inferred from these findings? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auditory neuropathy

 

If a child arrives with concerns about not being able to comprehend words, and their BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) results are abnormal while their PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry) results are normal, this could indicate the presence of auditory neuropathy.

 

Auditory neuropathy is a neurologic disorder of CN VIII. Audiometric tests, e.g. SNHL for pure tones, impaired speech discrimination score, absent or abnormal auditory brainstem response, show a retrocochlear type of lesion but OAEs are normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Michel aplasia also known as complete labyrinthine aplasia, is the most severe congenital inner ear malformation, characterized by complete absence of inner ear structures. This condition would present with profound hearing loss detected on PTA, not normal PTA results.

 

Option C. Malingering: Intentional falsification of hearing loss would likely be exposed by objective tests like BERA, which would not show the abnormal results observed in this case.

 

Option D. Cochlear otosclerosis shows Carhart’s notch (dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction) on PTA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auditory neuropathy should be suspected in patients who present with normal hearing sensitivity on pure tone audiometry but show significant difficulties with speech comprehension and abnormal brainstem evoked response audiometry results.

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Electron microscopy

 

  • Among the given options, electron microscopy will be the least useful in assessing nasal mucociliary clearance.
  • Electron microscopy -  can detect structural and functional abnormalities of cilia but do not detect any other abnormalities interfering with nasal mucociliary clearance. It is used to visualize the detailed architecture of cilia, which can help identify defects in ciliary structure responsible for impaired mucociliary transport, but it does not measure the actual transport or clearance function.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saccharin Test: This is a straightforward clinical test where a small amount of saccharin is placed on the nasal mucosa, and the time it takes for the subject to taste the sweetness is measured. This time reflects the mucociliary clearance rate.

 

Option C. Charcoal Powder Method: Involves placing a small amount of charcoal powder in the nose and timing how long it takes for it to appear in the pharynx, similarly assessing the clearance capability of the mucociliary apparatus.

 

Option D. Scintigraphy: This nuclear medicine test uses a small amount of radioactive material to track and record mucociliary transport and clearance, providing both functional and anatomical information about the nasal and sinus mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Test for mucociliary clearance is:
    • Saccharin with or without color test in vivo -   Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance.
    • Radioisotope transport testing in vivo
    • Measuring ciliary activity in vitro
    • Nasal nitric oxide -  Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value
    • Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction
    • Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results.
    • The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.

choices.text: Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries
Sphenopalatine artery
Greater palatine artery
Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the external carotid artery in Kiesselbach's plexus?(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery which in turn is a branch of internal carotid artery.

 

Arterial supply of the nose:

 

Internal carotid system -

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

 

External Carotid System -

 

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Sphenopalatine artery: Incorrect because the sphenopalatine artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery (itself a branch of the external carotid artery), contributes to the arterial supply of Kiesselbach's plexus. It gives rise to the nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.

 

Option C. Greater palatine artery: Incorrect because the septal branch of the greater palatine artery, also a branch of the maxillary artery from the external carotid system, supplies the nasal septum and participates in forming Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Option D. Septal branch of superior labial artery: Incorrect as this artery, a branch of the facial artery (which stems from the external carotid artery), is part of the blood supply to the Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

 

Educational objective

 

Kiesselbach's plexus -

 

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of greater palatine

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in given endoscopic view of the nasal cavity:(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior turbinate

 

Marked structure is Inferior turbinate.

 

  • Inferior turbinate is a separate bone, arranged longitudinally.
  • Attaches anteriorly with maxilla and posteriorly with palatine bone.
  • Also attached to lacrimal bone and uncinate process of ethmoid in between.
  • Over the bone, thick vascular mucosal tissue surrounds.
  • The vascular channels travel from posterior to anterior inside the turbinate mucosa, so that inspired air will be in exchange of moisture (humidification of inspired air) with vascular channels for a long duration.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Middle turbinate: This is located above the inferior turbinate and is part of the ethmoid bone. It plays a role in directing air flow and protecting sinus openings.

 

Option C. Superior turbinate: The smallest of the turbinates, located higher up in the nasal cavity and also part of the ethmoid bone.

 

Option D. Uncinate process: This is a part of the ethmoid bone that forms the anterior border of the hiatus semilunaris, involved in the drainage pathway of the sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior turbinate is a critical structure for the proper conditioning of air entering the respiratory system. Its large surface area and vascular mucosa play essential roles in the humidification and warming of inhaled air, contributing to the overall respiratory health and protection against pathogens and particulate matter.

questions.text: Which of these characteristics is not linked to superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sensorineural hearing loss

 

  • Conductive hearing loss is seen in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCDS).
  • “Third window” mechanism due to SCD and enlarged vestibular aqueduct. Schematic representations illustrate inner ear volume velocity with arrows -
    1. Normal anatomy allows volume velocity across the cochlear partition from the oval to the round window (two windows).
    2. Air conducted sound stimulation results in volume velocity from the stapes to be shunted toward the SCD (third window) and away from the cochlea, resulting in increased air-conduction thresholds at low frequencies and/or sound-induced vertigo (Tullio's phenomenon). Positive static pressure in the middle-ear cavity may result in ampullofugal fluid motion exciting the ampulla, resulting in nystagmus (Hennebert sign) and oscillopsia/vertigo.
    3. Elevated intracranial pressure from Valsalva against closed glottis (e.g., straining, heaving lifting) may result in ampullopetal endolymphatic fluid motion, inhibition of the ampulla, also leading to nystagmus (Hennebert sign) and oscillopsia/vertigo.
    4. Enlarged vestibular aqueduct (EVA) can also act as a third window, shunting volume velocity away from the cochlear partition and toward the widened vestibular aqueduct.

 

Gaze-evoked tinnitus or hyperacusis may also be seen.

 

 

  • High-resolution CT is the gold standard for identification of SSCD
  • Cervical VEMP sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing SSCDS ranges from 80% to 100%
  • Surgery is indicated only if symptoms are severe and disabling. Otherwise managed conservatively with medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaze dependent nystagmus: This can occur in SSCDS due to the abnormal transmission of fluid pressure waves through the "third window" created by the dehiscence, affecting the balance organs in the inner ear.

 

Option B. Positive Fistula test: This test, which involves applying pressure to the ear canal, can produce eye movements (nystagmus) or vertigo in cases of SSCDS due to the abnormal transmission of pressure to the inner ear.

 

Option D. Positive Tullio's phenomenon: This refers to sound-induced vertigo or nystagmus, which is a hallmark of SSCDS. The phenomenon occurs because sound vibrations lead to abnormal fluid dynamics in the inner ear due to the dehiscence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SSCDS, conductive hearing loss is typical due to the additional pathway for sound and pressure transmission created by the dehiscence, not sensorineural hearing loss, which involves damage to the hair cells in the cochlea or the auditory nerve. Understanding these distinct characteristics helps in accurately diagnosing and managing the condition.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 2, Page no. 843-847

questions.text: A 5-year-old presents with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratory distress for 2 weeks. Diagnosis is: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory papillomatosis

 

The given clinical situation suggests that the child is suffering from respiratory papillomatosis.

 

Respiratory Papillomatosis (Juvenile Papillomatosis)

 

  • It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is caused by HPV 6 and 11.
  • Involves supraglottic and glottic regions of larynx.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Age 3-5 years
  • Hoarseness or aphonia
  • Respiratory difficulty
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy

 

 

Treatment consists of cold steel/ coblation/ debrider/ radiofrequency/ Laser assisted microlaryngeal surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Croup: Though croup affects young children and presents with respiratory symptoms, it is an acute condition that generally presents rapidly with a characteristic barking cough and stridor, not gradually as in this case.

 

Option C. Vocal nodule: Vocal nodules result from vocal cord trauma and present symmetrically on the free edge of the vocal cords at the junction of the anterior one-third and the posterior two-thirds. They typically cause hoarseness but do not lead to respiratory distress, as they do not obstruct the airway.

 

Option D. Acute epiglottitis: This is another acute condition, presenting with rapid onset and severe symptoms including high fever, throat pain, and significant respiratory distress. The progressive nature of the symptoms described in the question does not align with the acute presentation of epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Juvenile respiratory papillomatosis should be considered in young children presenting with a gradual worsening of hoarseness and the development of respiratory symptoms. The condition highlights the need for awareness of HPV-related diseases in children and indicates the importance of early and accurate diagnosis followed by appropriate surgical intervention, which may include cold steel, coblation, debrider, radiofrequency, or laser-assisted microlaryngeal surgery to manage the growth and recurrence of papillomas effectively.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 327, 328, 343, 345, 346

questions.text:
Which of the following tests can be used if otoacoustic emissions is absent for screening?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure tone audiometry
  2. Tympanometry
  3. Free field audiometry
  4. Speech audiometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4

 

When otoacoustic emissions (OAE) are absent, it indicates a potential cochlear pathology, specifically affecting the outer hair cells. Further testing is required to assess the extent and nature of hearing loss, as well as to rule out any retrocochlear pathology.

 

2. Tympanometry: This test assesses the condition of the middle ear and tympanic membrane mobility by creating variations in air pressure in the ear canal. It is useful to determine if the absence of OAEs might be related to middle ear issues, such as fluid, which can mask cochlear function.

 

4. Speech Audiometry: This test evaluates the ability to understand speech and also provides information about the clarity of speech perception. It helps to determine the speech recognition threshold and is crucial for diagnosing the degree and type of hearing loss when OAEs are absent.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure Tone Audiometry: While this test is crucial for determining the threshold levels of hearing and the degree of hearing loss across different frequencies, it was not specified as one of the correct responses in this context.

 

3. Free Field Audiometry: Generally used for young children or individuals who cannot reliably use headphones, this test measures hearing sensitivity to sounds presented in an open field. However, it requires a controlled sound field, which is not always practical for immediate follow-up when OAEs are absent.

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 29

questions.text: Following a surgical procedure on the lateral aspect of the skull base, the patient experiences postoperative aspiration. However, there is no alteration in the patient's voice. What could be the explanation for this?(AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior laryngeal nerve injury

 

  • The patient has an injury to the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN).
  • SLN motor supply – cricothyroid muscle → when affected causes change in voice only in high pitch
  • SLN sensory supply – Above level of vocal cords → when affected can cause aspiration.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve doesn't provide either sensory or motor supply to the larynx so its lesion will not cause aspiration.
  • RLN supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid > when affected will cause change in voice.
  • A high vagal injury will affect both SLN and RLN, hence can also be ruled out.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury: This nerve does not primarily provide sensory or motor innervation to the larynx; its involvement would not typically result in aspiration.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury: Injury to this nerve would more likely affect the voice since it innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid. It would lead to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option D. High vagal injury: An injury here would affect both the SLN and the recurrent laryngeal nerve, likely causing symptoms in both voice and swallowing mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the superior laryngeal nerve, particularly its internal branch, is a plausible explanation for the patient's aspiration post-surgery, especially when there is no accompanying change in voice quality. This suggests that the sensory function above the vocal cords is compromised, increasing the risk of aspiration without necessarily affecting voice modulation handled by the external laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: What is the definitive approach for managing uncontrollable vertigo caused by Meniere's disease?(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Labyrinthectomy

 

Definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Meniere’s disease is labyrinthectomy.

 

The step-up management of Meniere’s disease is

 

  1. Dietary changes – low salt and caffeine free diet
  2. First-line medical treatment to prevent recurrence of vertigo may include betahistine dihydrochloride 16 mg thrice daily and/or diuretics. Betahistine has a limited side effect profile while diuretics can cause electrolyte disturbances, potentially interacting with patient-specific drugs and conditions.
  3. Salvage treatment in case of medical treatment failure may include repetitive intratympanic injections of dexamethasone.
  4. In refractory cases after intratympanic injection of dexamethasone, intratympanic injection of gentamicin (as-needed) can be offered (recommendation grade A). This treatment is based on the vestibulotoxic effect of gentamicin and aims to destroy vestibular hair cell function (therefore also called partial chemo labyrinthectomy).
  5. Surgical destruction (Labyrinthectomy, Vestibular nerve section): Labyrinthectomy totally destroys cochlear and vestibular function and are thus used only when cochlear function is not serviceable and when conservative treatments fail. It has shown the highest rate of vertigo control (>95%), and is considered as the single definitive treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetazolamide: This medication is not typically used as a definitive treatment for Meniere's disease. It may be used in some cases for its diuretic effect to manage symptoms, but it does not address the root causes or provide long-term control of vertigo.

 

Option C. Vestibular neurectomy: This surgical procedure involves severing the vestibular nerve to alleviate vertigo while preserving hearing. It is considered for patients where hearing preservation is a priority, but it is not as definitive as labyrinthectomy for completely eliminating vertigo.

 

Option D. Intratympanic gentamicin: This treatment involves injecting gentamicin, a vestibulotoxic antibiotic, into the middle ear to chemically ablate vestibular function. It is used as a salvage treatment for vertigo control in Meniere's disease when other medical treatments fail. However, it is not considered as definitive as labyrinthectomy due to its potential for hearing loss and the need for repeated treatments in some cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with Meniere's disease who have debilitating vertigo and no serviceable hearing in the affected ear, labyrinthectomy offers a definitive solution with a very high success rate in eliminating vertigo. This surgical option is reserved for severe cases where other less invasive treatments have been exhausted.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis for the past 6 months. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) JNA

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males. The typical presentation includes nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis (nosebleeds).

Other Options:

 

Option B. Allergic Rhinitis: Nasal obstruction but no recurrent epistaxis.

 

Option C. Coagulation Disorder: Bleeding from multiple sites, not specific to nasal obstruction in adolescent males.

 

Option D. Antrochoanal Polyp: Nasal obstruction without recurrent epistaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is the most likely diagnosis for a 13-year-old boy with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis, as it commonly presents in adolescent males with these symptoms.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway:(INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-1-3-4-5

 

The correct sequence of the auditory pathway is spiral ganglion - cochlear nucleus - superior olivary nucleus - inferior colliculus - medial geniculate body.

 

2. Spiral Ganglion : The spiral ganglion is situated in Rosenthal's canal and contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve, which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

 

1. Cochlear Nucleus : The cochlear nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

3. Superior Olivary Nucleus : After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary nucleus.

 

4. Inferior Colliculus : From the superior olivary nucleus, the auditory signals travel to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

5. Medial Geniculate Body : The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA).

 

  1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
  2. Cochlear Nucleus
  3. Superior Olivary nucleus
  4. Lateral lemniscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Medial geniculate body
  7. Auditory cortex

questions.text: Which structures pass between superior and middle constrictor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal Nerve)

 

The pharyngeal constrictor muscles are organized into three main parts: the superior, middle, and inferior constrictors. Each of these muscles plays a crucial role in the mechanics of swallowing and speech.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passes between the superior and middle constrictor muscles. This is a key anatomical relationship to remember as it is crucial for the nerve supply to the pharynx.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eustachian Tube: Passes through the sinus of Morgagni, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option C. Superior Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the middle and inferior constrictors, not the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option D. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the inferior constrictor and the esophagus, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal nerve) and the stylopharyngeus muscle pass between the superior and middle constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

choices.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

questions.text:
A woman presents with impaired hearing. Her audiometry findings are given below:  (INICET Nov 2021)

 

 

Pick the right combination of tuning fork test results that would be seen in this patient. (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

 

Based on the provided tympanogram findings, it is likely that the tuning fork tests for this patient would reveal a positive left Rinne test and Weber test lateralized to the right ear (normal ear).

 

 

INTERPRETATION OF AUDIOGRAM

 

  • Whenever a PTA is given, first see whether there is air-bone gap (AC & BC curves are separated by a long gap) or not
  • If there is no air-bone gap or very little gap, then it could be sensorineural hearing loss.
  • If there is a long separation in between the AC & BC curves, then it could be either conductive or mixed.
  • First see whether the distantly separated curves are present in the upper part of the graph or lower part.
  • If occupying upper part, then it is conductive hearing loss and if occupying lower part, then it could be mixed.
  • In the question given above, left sided air conduction and bone conduction curves do not have any gap and they are occupying middle part of the graph. Hence, it is left SNHL.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear: This result would be expected in conductive hearing loss, not SNHL.

 

Option B. Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear: This also indicates conductive hearing loss, which is not supported by the audiogram findings.

 

Option D. Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear: This would indicate normal hearing or mild hearing loss in the right ear, which does not match the audiogram showing significant SNHL in the left ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sensorineural hearing loss, Rinne's test remains positive, and Weber's test lateralizes to the better-hearing ear. The provided audiogram indicates left-sided SNHL, resulting in a positive Rinne test on the left and Weber lateralizing to the right ear.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 24, 25

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea and vomiting. On investigation, there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meniere’s disease

The patient's symptoms and the diagnostic finding of endolymphatic hypertension align with Meniere's disease. 

Characterized by episodes of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, lasting from minutes to hours. The symptoms are due to the accumulation of fluid in the inner ear (endolymphatic hydrops), leading to increased pressure within the endolymphatic system.

Other Options:

 Option B. Otosclerosis: A condition primarily affecting the bones of the middle ear, particularly the stapes. It causes conductive hearing loss, not typically associated with vertigo or tinnitus of the type seen in Meniere’s disease.

Option C. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV): Characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to changes in head position. It involves the dislodgment of otoliths within the inner ear, leading to brief, intense episodes of vertigo, without the auditory symptoms typical of Meniere's disease. 

Option D. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma): A benign tumor on the vestibular nerve, leading to progressive, unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances. It usually does not cause episodic vertigo like Meniere's disease.

Educational Objective:

Meniere’s disease is a chronic condition that requires management of symptoms through lifestyle changes, medications to control vertigo, and sometimes more invasive treatments to manage fluid pressure in the inner ear.

questions.text: An individual who is experiencing vertigo but does not have hearing impairment has consulted an ENT surgeon. The surgeon proceeds with a diagnostic technique followed by a carefully executed therapeutic procedure. What is the diagnostic maneuver?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dix-Hallpike maneuver

 

Vertigo without hearing loss diagnosed by a positional maneuver is benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnostic maneuver used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver and therapeutic maneuver is the Epley's maneuver.

 

Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

 

  • Gold standard for diagnosing BPPV. 
  •  Nystagmus has a short latency period of 2-20 seconds, lasts for less than a minute, and has a fixed direction towards the lower placed ear, and is fatigable.
  • Associated with vertigo.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hampton's maneuver: This is not a widely recognized or standard maneuver in the diagnosis or treatment of vertigo. It does not relate to any commonly accepted procedure in the management of vertigo in otolaryngology.

 

Option C. Epley's maneuver: The therapeutic maneuver is the Epley maneuver which repositions the otolith to the utricle/saccule from the posterior semicircular canal.

 

 

Option D. Simon's maneuver: Like Hampton's maneuver, Simon's maneuver is not a standard or widely recognized technique in the diagnosis or management of vertigo associated with BPPV or other inner ear conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is specifically used for diagnosing BPPV by eliciting nystagmus induced by position changes.
  • The Epley's maneuver is used to treat the vertigo symptoms once BPPV is confirmed by the Dix-Hallpike test.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 47

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used for managing a patient with B/L external auditory canal atresia?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A.

 

 

Image A shows Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) and it can be used in managing B/L external auditory canal atresia.

 

INDICATIONS FOR BAHA

 

  1. When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
  2. Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment.
  3. Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment.
  4. Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid.
  5. Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g., otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated.
  6. Single-sided hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cochlear implant is an electronic device that can provide useful hearing and improved communication abilities for persons who have severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

 

Cochlear implants may be used both in children and adults. The following criteria help define candidacy for cochlear implantation:

 

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Little or no benefit from hearing aids.
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery.
  4. Realistic expectation.
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation.
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device.

 

Option C. Stapedectomy piston is used in otosclerosis patients.

 

Option D. Partial ossicular replacement prosthesis is used to replace the incudo-stapedial joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with bilateral external auditory canal atresia, BAHA is an excellent management option, leveraging bone conduction to bypass the outer and middle ear, thus facilitating hearing when traditional air-conduction devices cannot be used.

questions.text: Which of these labeled structures represents a division of the internal carotid artery? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

The structure marked 1 and 4 are the anterior ethmoidal artery and posterior ethmoidal artery, which are branches of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vascular Supply of the Nasal Cavity:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of minor trauma 20 days back with a piece of wood. He presented as shown in the image. CT scan revealed clear sinuses and the presence of subcutaneous nodules. Microscopy of the tissue sections are positive to PAS and positive on Gomori methamine silver stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis.

 

It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.

 

PATHOLOGY – From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain. The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES – Black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.

 

DIAGNOSIS – Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.

 

Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast MRI.

 

TREATMENT – Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: Primarily involves destructive lesions of the midline facial structures but lacks the fungal component.

 

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Typically arises from a reaction to a foreign material but would not cause the extensive symptoms or be positive on the fungal stains used.

 

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: Associated with elevated levels of IgG4 and typically presents with tumefactive lesions, not primarily infectious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phycomycosis is a serious fungal infection affecting mainly the nasal passages and sinuses, identifiable by special staining techniques and known for its aggressive, potentially fatal progression requiring prompt treatment with antifungals and surgery.

questions.text: Identify the blue line shown in the below picture:(AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ohngren's line

 

  • Ohngren's line is an imaginary line passing through the medial canthus of the eye and angle of mandible.
  • It is used for classification of maxillary carcinoma.
  • Growth situated above the plane - Suprastructure - Poor Prognosis
  • Growth situated below the plane - Infrastructure - Good Prognosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frankfurt horizontal line, the line passing through the inferior border of infraorbital rim and superior border of external auditory canal, is one of the most widely used intracranial landmarks in cephalometric analysis.

 

 

Option B. Donaldson line is an imaginary line drawn posteriorly from the course of the horizontal semicircular canal, used to identify endolymphatic sac during endolymphatic sac decompression surgery for meniere’s disease.

 

 

Option C. According to Lederman’s classification, 2 horizontal lines called lines of Sebileau pass through orbit floor and maxillary sinus, producing Suprastructure, mesostructure and infrastructure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ohngren's line is used to classify maxillary carcinomas into suprastructure and infrastructure based on their location relative to the line, which is critical for determining the prognosis and approach for surgical intervention.

questions.text: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has minimally spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage IB

 

According to Radkowski, the staging system mass in the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension, indicates Stage IB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IA: This stage involves tumors limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx, without any extension into the sinuses.

 

Option C. Stage IIA: Describes minimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossa, which is not indicated in this patient.

 

Option D. Stage IIB: Indicates occupation of the entire pterygopalatine fossa with or without erosion of the orbital apex, which also does not apply to this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

THE RADKOWSKI STAGING SYSTEM FOR JUVENILE NASOPHARYNGEAL ANGIOFIBROMA

choices.text: Partial fixation of footplate of stapes

questions.text: What causes maximum hearing loss? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ossicular discontinuity with intact TM

 

Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane causes maximum hearing loss (around 50 dB) because:

 

  • Sound waves can only travel through the ossicular chain when it is intact
  • When there's a break in the ossicular chain, sound transmission is completely interrupted
  • With intact TM, there's no alternative pathway for sound to reach the inner ear
  • The sound waves get dampened at the point of discontinuity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis media with effusion

 

  • Causes mild conductive hearing loss (30-35 dB)
  • Middle ear filled with serous fluid still allows some sound transmission
  • Common in children with adenoid hypertrophy blocking Eustachian tube

 

Option B. Partial fixation of footplate of stapes

 

  • Represents early otosclerosis
  • Causes mild conductive hearing loss as stapes can still move partially
  • Less severe than complete ossicular discontinuity

 

Option D. Malleus-incus disruption with TM disruption

 

  • Causes around 40 dB hearing loss
  • Less severe than option C because sound waves can reach round window directly through the perforation
  • Provides an alternative pathway for sound transmission

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane causes maximum hearing loss (50 dB) because sound waves have no alternative pathway to reach the inner ear.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

 

The correct match for Wullstein’s classification is a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

 

  1. Type II – 2. graft placed over the incus
  2. Type III – 4. columella tympanoplasty
  3. Type IV – 3. Cavum minor
  4. Type V – 1. Fenestration tympanoplasty

 

  1. Type II (Ossiculoplasty): Malleus partially eroded; ossicular chain reconstruction involves placing a graft over the incus.
  2. Type III (Columella Effect): Malleus and incus eroded; new TM coupled to the stapes head, referred to as columella tympanoplasty.
  3. Type IV (Cavum Minor): Stapedial head also eroded; new TM and new ossicular coupling to the stapes footplate.
  4. Type V (Fenestration Operation): Creating a fenestra and coupling the ossicular chain to the scala vestibuli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wullstein’s classification of tympanoplasty provides a systematic approach to different types of middle ear reconstructions based on the extent of ossicular damage and required surgical repair.

questions.text: A patient presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt. He underwent myringoplasty for the safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) 6 months back. What is your diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perilymphatic fistula

 

  • The clinical scenario with symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt and history of myringoplasty done for CSOM suggest that the diagnosis is perilymphatic fistula.
  • A peri-lymphatic fistula is an abnormal communication between the inner ear and the middle ear that can allow perilymph to leak from the cochlea or vestibule, most commonly through the round or oval window.
  • Precipitating causes include surgery, blunt trauma, penetrating trauma, barotrauma, infection, cholesteatoma, or sudden changes in CSF pressure as can occur with straining, sneezing, or Valsalva’s maneuver. Congenital ear abnormalities may predispose to perilymph leaks. Spontaneous perilymph fistulae are rare.
  • The clinical picture of perilymph fistulae is variable, with symptoms ranging from mild to incapacitating. Vertigo, or more often unsteadiness, is the most common symptom. Hearing loss, tinnitus, or aural fullness may be present. A thorough history inquiring about activities such as trauma, scuba diving, flying, and straining is critical in the diagnosis of this disorder as the symptoms are vague and coincident with other vestibular disorders. Fistula test is positive.

 

Investigations

 

  • HRCT temporal bone has high sensitivity in detecting peri lymphatic fistula.
  • A combination of CT and MRI diagnose almost 100% of cases.
  • Other tests include audiometry and electrocochleography.

 

Management of a peri-lymphatic fistula is either by conservative or surgical methods. Conservative therapy includes avoiding anything that can increase inner ear or intracranial pressure and the use of intratympanic steroids in acute decompensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labyrinthitis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating and pallor and sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option C. Paget's disease of bone usually presents with hearing loss as a prominent feature, when the skull is involved. It is not associated with a history of surgery, trauma or vestibulocochlear symptoms.

 

Option D. Vestibular Schwannoma, also called as acoustic neuroma is a tumor that arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular, but rarely from the cochlear division of vestibulocochlear nerve within the internal auditory canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perilymphatic fistula should be suspected in patients presenting with vestibular symptoms following ear surgery, particularly when associated with activities that change intracranial or middle ear pressure. Diagnosis is largely based on clinical history, symptomatology, and specific imaging tests.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo associated with horizontal nystagmus. The slow component is towards the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left hypoactive labyrinth

 

  • A left hypoactive labyrinth is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features.
  • Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component.
  • The fast component denotes the direction of the nystagmus.
  • Paretic lesions such as purulent labyrinthitis, and trauma to the labyrinth cause nystagmus to the healthy side.
  • Serous labyrinthitis (irritative lesion) leads to nystagmus on the same side of the lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior canal BPPV: Characterized by positional vertigo and typically vertical nystagmus, related to the posterior semicircular canal.

 

Option B. Superior canal BPPV: Also known as anterior canal BPPV, would cause primarily vertically oriented nystagmus, not horizontal.

 

Option C. Right hypoactive labyrinth: Would produce nystagmus with the slow component towards the right and the fast component towards the left, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The direction of the slow and fast components of nystagmus is crucial in diagnosing the affected side in vestibular disorders. A left hypoactive labyrinth leads to nystagmus with a fast component to the right, matching the clinical presentation in this scenario.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 43

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Super supraglottic swallow

 

Super supraglottic swallow is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation but in dysphagia to prevent aspiration of food.

 

The Super-Supraglottic Swallow technique is employed for patients experiencing diminished airway closure. To perform this technique, patients are directed to take a deep breath and tightly hold it while bearing down. They should maintain this breath hold and bear down as they swallow. Immediately after the swallow (before inhaling), they are instructed to cough, followed by a forceful swallow once more (before inhaling). This sequence is aimed at enhancing airway protection during swallowing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP) is a one-way valve inserted through a tracheoesophageal puncture. Occlusion of the stoma shunts the exhaled air through the TEP into the esophagus producing vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter resulting in phonation.

Option B. Esophageal speech is phonation produced by vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter.

 

Option C. Polite yawning also called nasal airflow-inducing maneuver is indicated for olfaction rehabilitation post laryngectomy. This maneuver induces a negative pressure in the oral cavity and oropharynx, which generates a nasal airflow, enabling odorous substances to reach the olfactory epithelium again.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Super supraglottic swallow technique is crucial for enhancing airway protection in dysphagia management but is not utilized in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation, where the focus is primarily on restoring voice and smell functions through other specialized techniques.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition 352, 353; Scott Brown 7th edition, Volume 2, Page No. 2090

questions.text: Foreign body entry into the laryngeal inlet is prevented by the cough reflex. This reflex is sluggish in alcohol ingestion and some other conditions. Which nerve is likely injured?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal laryngeal nerve

 

Cough reflex is a protective mechanism of the larynx to expel foreign irritants in order to keep airway clear. Afferent of this reflex is through internal laryngeal nerve, which gives sensory supply to mucosa above vocal cords. Irritant substances like alcohol affects the nervous system causing inhibition of cough reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Primarily involved in the sensation and taste on the posterior one-third of the tongue, not directly involved in the cough reflex at the larynx.

 

Option C. External laryngeal nerve: Mainly supplies the cricothyroid muscle with motor fibers and does not have a sensory role in the cough reflex.

 

Option D. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: Supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid and provides sensory innervation to the mucosa below the vocal cords; thus, it plays a role in the cough reflex but primarily for the lower part of the larynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to or inhibition of the internal laryngeal nerve can significantly impair the cough reflex by reducing the sensory input required to detect irritants above the vocal cords, emphasizing its pivotal role in this protective reflex.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 337
